member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an API is experimental and it may change in the future.
member.remarks: This attribute allows call sites to be flagged with a diagnostic that indicates that an experimental feature is used. Authors can use this attribute to ship preview features in their assemblies.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.param: The ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.DiagnosticId
member.summary: Gets the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.remarks:
The diagnostic ID is shown in build output for warnings and errors.
This property represents the unique ID that can be used to suppress the warnings or errors, if needed.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.UrlFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL for corresponding documentation. The API accepts a format string instead of an actual URL, creating a generic URL that includes the diagnostic ID.
member.value: The format string that represents a URL to corresponding documentation.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SetsRequiredMembersAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that this constructor sets all required members for the current type, and callers do not need to set any required members themselves.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.name: T:System.Index
member.summary: Represent a type can be used to index a collection either from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Construct an Index using a value and indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.param: The index value. it has to be zero or positive number.
Indicating if the index is from the start or from the end.
member.remarks: If the Index constructed from the end, index value 1 means pointing at the last element and index value 0 means pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: P:System.Index.Start
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at first element.

member.name: P:System.Index.End
member.summary: Create an Index pointing at beyond last element.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromStart(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the start at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the start.

member.name: M:System.Index.FromEnd(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create an Index from the end at the position indicated by the value.
member.param: The index value from the end.

member.name: P:System.Index.Value
member.summary: Returns the index value.

member.name: P:System.Index.IsFromEnd
member.summary: Indicates whether the index is from the start or the end.

member.name: M:System.Index.GetOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the offset from the start using the giving collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter and the returned offset value against negative values. we don't validate either the returned offset is greater than the input length. It is expected Index will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. If the returned offset is negative and then used to index a collection will get out of range exception which will be same affect as the validation.

member.name: M:System.Index.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current Index object is equal to another object of the same type.
member.param: An object to compare with this object

member.name: M:System.Index.Equals(System.Index)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current Index object is equal to another Index object.
member.param: An object to compare with this object

member.name: M:System.Index.GetHashCode
member.summary: Returns the hash code for this instance.

member.name: M:System.Index.op_Implicit(System.Int32)~System.Index
member.summary: Converts integer number to an Index.

member.name: M:System.Index.ToString
member.summary: Converts the value of the current Index object to its equivalent string representation.

member.summary: Create a Range object starting from start index to the end of the collection.

member.name: M:System.Range.EndAt(System.Index)
member.summary: Create a Range object starting from first element in the collection to the end Index.

member.name: P:System.Range.All
member.summary: Create a Range object starting from first element to the end.

member.name: M:System.Range.GetOffsetAndLength(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate the start offset and length of range object using a collection length.
member.param: The length of the collection that the range will be used with. length has to be a positive value.
member.remarks: For performance reason, we don't validate the input length parameter against negative values. It is expected Range will be used with collections which always have non negative length/count. We validate the range is inside the length scope though.

member.remarks: This should match the metadata name of the target method. For example, this might be ".ctor" if targeting the type's constructor.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RequiredMemberAttribute

member.name: F:BizHawk.WinForms.Controls.Docs.TypeNamePrefix
member.remarks:
This project has some naming conventions in regards to type names.
Loc* are positionable; instances should set . The intention is for controls without Loc to be used in FLPs.
Sz* are resizable; instances should set . is always set for you, with or without this prefix.
These combine as expected. A type name without any prefix is the most restrictive, having many properties pre-set (which is a double-edged sword as they can't be changed).
In addition, properties are hidden in the Designer (with ) when they are read-only and their value is clear from the type name.

member.name: T:BizHawk.WinForms.Controls.IRadioButtonReadOnlyTracker
member.summary: Functions as a write-only collection of ITrackedRadioButtons.
member.remarks: Elements should have unique Names; breaking this rule is UB, not checked at runtime.

member.name: P:BizHawk.WinForms.Controls.ITrackedRadioButton.Checked
member.remarks: Does not declare a setter intentionally, use .

member.name: T:BizHawk.WinForms.Controls.RadioButtonGroupTracker
member.summary:
Functions as a collection of ITrackedRadioButtons.
Using this in our custom GroupBoxes circumvents the direct-child restriction on radio buttons. With that gone, we're free to use nested FLPs in our layouts, the cost being the complexity of this class and its related types.
member.remarks: Elements should have unique Names; breaking this rule is UB, not checked at runtime.

member.returns: The of the selected radio button, cast to ?, or if no button is selected or if the collection is empty.
